column4: Good evening, I have a small network at home with 6 computers running ubuntu.  On each i have thunderbird for email.  Its nice, but each one has to redownload emails.  On the head of my network is a server (gateway).  Is it possible to use this server to download the emails then the 5 clients download from the server as if it were downloading using the standard method?
There are a number of ways to deal with this problem.
The best is to use IMAP and store your email on your mail server, but not all mail servers support this.
So one way to do it is to set your gateway to download mail once via "fetchmail"
And then, set up an IMAP server on that gateway.  This is a pain to set up, but it's a good solution.
: is there any script or easier way of doing this?
Not that I know of.  The easier way to do it is to get a mail server that supports IMAP - there are other ways to do it, but none of them are very easy
: is there any how-to or turorial you're aware of on the www
Well, there are all sorts of tutorials for installing fetchmail, and then after that there are all sorts of tutorials for installing an IMAP server
But I don't know which are the best for Ubuntu in particular, and I haven't done it in years anyway
Basically, your options are:
: I think in my situation, the remote SSH (with x forwarding) across my network with thunderbird would be the best option
Okay.  That is easier to set up.
: I am not competent enough to mess with email servers (yet?) but ssh is within my grasp.  thank you for your help
Good luck.  Remember that you don't necessarily need SSH forwarding over your home network - you can use X without encryption
If this seems insecure, remember that downloading mail via POP is almost always plaintext over the internet anyway =)
X itself is meant to be run over a network.  That's how it's designed.  So you can do two things:
You can use ssh to launch the command on one machine but displaying on another
(I haven't done this in a long time)
yes that is what i was talking about
Or you can directly log on to that machine remotely.  Ubuntu's login screen supports logging in elsewhere using XDMCP or something - my acronym might be mixed up there
i am aware of these methods of x forwarding

The difference is that SSH with X forwarding is tunneled through SSH and is encrypted, while using SSH to launch the program doesn't necessarily have to be.  But now that I think about it...  X forwarding is much easier to set up and more robust.  So I guess that is a better option.
Okay.  I think I've reached the limit of my knowledge now, but good luck
